sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: By my troth sir as ye see,
Acorns are good enough for such as he.
I wish his honour well, and to do him good:
Would he had eaten all the acorns in th'wood.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Good words Joculo, of your lord and mine.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: As may agree with such a churlish swine.
How does his honour?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Indifferently well.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I wish him better.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Vicegerent in hell.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Dost thou wish so, for ought that he hath done?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I for the love he bears unto his son.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: He's grown of late, as fatherly and mild,
As ever father was unto his child:
And sent me forth to search the coast about,
If so my hap might be to find him out.
And if Eurymine alive remain,
To bring them both unto the court again.
Where is thy master?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Walking about the ground.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: O that his love Eurymine were found.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why so she is, come follow me and see.
I'll bring ye straight where they remaining be.

div.stage: Enter three or four muses, Aramanthus, Ascanio, Silvio, and Gemulo.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Cease your contention for Eurymine.
Nor words, nor vows, can help her misery:
But he it is that did her first transform,
Must calm the gloomy rigor of this storm:
Great Phoebus, whose palace we are near,
Salute him then in his celestial sphere:
That with the notes of cheerful harmony,
He may be moved to show his deity.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But where's Eurymine, have we lost her sight?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Poor soul, within a cave, with fear affright
She sits to shun Apollo's angry view,
Until she see what of our prayers ensue:
If we can reconcile his love or no,
Or that she must continue in her woe.

sp.speaker: 1. Mu
sp.l: Once have we tried Ascanio, for thy sake
And once again we will his power awake:
Not doubting but as he is of heavenly race,
at length he will take pity on her case.
Sing therefore, and each party from his heart,
In this our music, bear a cheerful part.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: All hail fair Phoebus, in thy purple throne,
Vouchsafe the regarding of our deep moan.
Hide not, o hide not, thy comfortable face,
But pity, but pity, a virgin's poor case.

sp.speaker: 1. Muse.
sp.l: Illustrate beauty, crystal heaven's eye,
Once more we do entreat thy clemency:
That as thou art the power of us all,
Thou wouldst redeem Eurymine from thrall.
Grant gentle God, grant this our small request,
And if ability in us do rest:
Whereby we ever may deserve the same,
It shall be seen, we reverence Phoebus name.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: You sacred sisters of fair Hellion,
On whom my favours evermore have shone,
In this you must have patience with my vow,
I cannot grant what you aspire unto.
Nor was't my fault, she was transformed so,
But her own fond desire, as ye well know.
We told her too, before her vow was passed,
That cold repentance would ensue at last.
And sith herself did wish the shape of man,
She caused the abuse, digest it how she can.

sp.speaker: 2. Muse.
sp.l: Alas, if unto her you be so hard,
Yet of Ascanio have some more regard,
And let him not endure such endless wrong,
That hath pursued her constant love so long.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Great God, the grievous travels I have passed,
In restless search, to find her out at last:
My plaints my toils, in lieu of my annoy,
Have well deserved my lady to enjoy.
Penance too much I have sustained before:
O Phoebus, plague me not with any more.
Nor be thou so extreme, now at the worst
To make my torments greater than at the first
My father's late displeasure is forgotten,
And there's no let, nor any churlish blot
To interrupt our joys from being complete,
But only thy good favour to entreat:
In thy great grace it lies to make my state
Most happy now, or most infortunate.

sp.speaker: 1. Mu
sp.l: Heavenly Apollo, on our knees I pray,
Vouchsafe thy great displeasure to allay.
What honour to thy godhead will arise,
To plague a silly lady in this wise?
Beside, it is a stain unto thy deity,
To yield thine own desires the sovereignty:
Then show some grace unto a woeful dame,
And in these groves, our tongues shall sound thy fame.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Arise dear nurses of divinest skill,
You sacred muses of Parnassus hill:
Phoebus is conquered by your dear respect,
And will no longer clemency neglect.
You have not sued nor prayed to me in vain:
I grant your wills, she is a maid again.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Thy praise shall never die whilst I do live.

sp.speaker: 2. Mu
sp.l: Nor will we slack perpetual thanks to give.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thalia, near the cave where she remains
The fairies keep, request them of their pains,
And in my name, bid them forthwith provide,
From that dark place, to be the ladies' guide.
And in the bounty of their liberal mind,
To give her clothes according to her kind.

sp.speaker: 1. Mu
sp.l: I go divine Apollo.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Haste again.
No time too swift, to ease a lover's pain.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Most sacred Phoebus, endless thanks to thee,
That dost vouchsafe so much to pity me.
And aged father, for your kindness shown,
Imagine not your friendship ill bestown.
The earth shall sooner vanish and decay,
Than I will prove unthankful any way.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: It is sufficient recompense to me,
If that my silly help have pleasured ye.
If you enjoy your love and heart's desire,
It is enough: nor do I more require.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Grave Aramanthus, now I see thy face
I call to mind, how tedious a long space
Thou hast frequented these sad deserts here,
Thy time employed, in heedful mind I bear:
The patient sufferance of thy former wrong,
Thy poor estate, and sharp exile so long,
The honourable port thou borest sometime,
Till wronged thou wast, with undeserved crime
By them whom thou to honour didst advance,
The memory of which thy heavy chance,
Provokes my mind to take remorse on thee,
Father henceforth, my client shalt thou be:
And pass the remnant of thy fleeting time,
With laurel wreath, amongst the Muses nine.
And when thy age hath given place to fate,
Thou shalt exchange thy former mortal state:
And after death, a palm of fame shalt wear,
Amongst the rest that live in honour here.
And lastly know, that fair Eurymine
Redeemed now from former misery
Thy daughter is, whom I for that intent
Did hide from thee, in this thy banishment:
That so she might the greater scourge sustain,
In putting Phoebus to so great a pain.
But freely now, enjoy each others sight:
No more Eurymine: abandon quite
That borrowed name, as Atlanta, she is called,
And here she woman, in her right shape installed.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Is then my love derived of noble race?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: No more of that, but mutually embrace.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.l: Lives my Atlanta, whom the rough sea's wave
I thought had brought unto a timeless grave?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Look not so strange, it is thy father's voice.
And this thy love: Atlanta now rejoice.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: As in another world of greater bliss
My daunted spirits do stand amazed at this.
So great a tide of comfort overflows,
As what to say, my faltering tongue scarce knows:
But only this, unperfect though it be,
Immortal thanks great Phoebus unto thee.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Well lady, you are retransformed now,
But I am sure you did repent your vow.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.l: Bright lamp of glory, pardon my rashness past

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The penance was your own, though I did fast

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Behold dear love, to make your joys abound,
Yonder Phylander comes.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O sir, well found.
But most especially it glads my mind,
To see my mistress restored to kind.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: My lord and madam, to requite your pain,
Telemachus hath sent for you again.
All former quarrels now are trodden down,
And he doth smile, that heretofore did frown.

sp.speaker: Asca.
sp.l: Thanks kind Phylander, for thy friendly news
Like Juno's balm, that our life's blood renews.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: But lady, first ere you your journey take,
Vouchsafe at my request, one grant to make.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The matter is but small.
To wear a branch of laurel in your cawl
For Phoebus sake, lest else I be forgotten,
And think upon me, when you see me not.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Here while I live a solemn oath I make,
To love the laurel for Apollo's sake.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Our suit is dashed, we may depart I see.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Nay Gemulo and Silvio, contented be:
This night let me entreat ye you will take,
Such cheer as I and these poor dames can make.
Tomorrow morn we'll bring you on your way.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Your godhead shall command us all to stay.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Then ladies gratulate this happy chance,
With some delightful tune and pleasant dance.
Mean space, upon his harp will Phoebus play,
So both of them may boast another day
And make report, that when their wedding chanced,
Phoebus gave music, and the Muses danced.

lg.head: The song.
lg.l: Since painful sorrow's date hath end,
And time hath coupled friend with friend:
Rejoice we all, rejoice and sing,
Let all these groves of Phoebus' ring.
Hope having won, despair is vanished:
Pleasure revives, and care is banished.
Then trip we all this roundelay,
And still be mindful of the bay.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
